Allah explains the challenge of the polytheists of Mecca to the Messenger of Allah. If what the Messenger said was true, namely the existence of the Day of Resurrection, then he should present proof of its truth and revive their ancestors who had died before. According to them, if the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) could resurrect (from the grave) and revive their ancestors, then this could be proof of the existence of the Day of Resurrection.

Then Allah explains that He is able to gather things that are scattered, starting from solids, liquids, and air, from the smallest atoms to molecules, all gathered into one so that a human being is formed. Does man know where the food he eats comes from, the clothes he wears, the household appliances they use, and so on? All come from distant corners of the world, then gathered by God in one place to fulfill the needs and desires of a human being. If Allah can do such a thing, then gathering scattered bones, flesh that has been destroyed and turned into soil, and records of the deeds that a person has done is easier for Him to do; repeating something that once existed is much easier than making it for the first time.

From this explanation, it can be concluded that the Day of Resurrection will definitely occur. Only the time is not yet known and only Allah knows it. What is clear is that the Day of Resurrection will occur after the entire universe experiences total destruction, including all its contents. That is why Allah did not respond to the challenge of the polytheists, because it is useless to answer it. They put forward the challenge only to cover up the contents and desires of their hearts. Whether their request is granted or not, they will still not believe.
text.37:
Then Allah reminds them of the people who were struck by calamity and Allah's punishment, because they were disobedient and did not heed the calls of the messengers sent to them. They should guard themselves, lest Allah punish them as the previous people had experienced. Allah states that their condition is no better than the people of Tubba'.

Sahl bin Sa'd said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah say: 'Do not revile Tubba' because he has already embraced Islam.'" (Narrated by Ahmad)

Tubba' is the title for the kings of Himyar in Yemen. Their people are called the people of Tubba'. They committed sins that exceeded the limits, so their country was destroyed by Allah. However, some of their people still lived, wandering to neighboring countries. Initially, they were a people with considerable ability and knowledge, and had a strong army. Compared to the people of Tubba', the disbelievers of Mecca were far behind. Allah states that the disbelievers of Mecca are no better off than the people of 'Ad and Thamud. These two peoples were also destroyed by Allah because of their arrogance and denial of the existence of the Day of Resurrection.

At the end of this verse, Allah emphasizes that *sunnatullah* has been in effect for past nations. They were all destroyed because they were immersed in the mire of disobedience. This event should be a lesson for the disbelievers of Mecca if they would take a lesson. In another verse, Allah affirms this *sunnah* of His. Allah says:

"That was the way of Allah with those who passed away before; and you will not find in the way of Allah any change." (al-Ahzab/33: 62)
text.38:
Allah explains that the heavens and the earth and everything in them were not created in vain or by chance without purpose and intention, but everything was created according to Allah's plan and will. If one carefully observes every life on earth and all the events in the sky, one will surely know the benefits of both animate and inanimate creatures of various levels, from the lowest to the highest, there are provisions that apply to them, and there is also a time determined for their lives.

For example, a bird is hatched from an egg that comes from its mother. After being incubated for a certain time, a small, featherless chick emerges from the egg. Day by day, the chick is fed by its mother, so that the chick grows gradually, its body becomes larger and covered with feathers, and its wings become stronger. Then it is taught by its mother to fly, it flies from branch to branch, guided by its mother to find food and drink. After reaching adulthood, it begins to carry out its life's task, seeking a mate to develop offspring. When its time comes, it dies like other birds.

If observed, it seems as if the birds carry a mission in life. Allah has decreed that the bird's food is insects, and insects eat and damage plants planted by humans. It is as if the bird is helping human efforts and life. The bird, with its melodious voice and chirping, pleases and soothes the hearts of those who hear it. Bacteria, a type of fine and small animal, and also worms seem to have no use at all. If observed, bacteria and worms eat waste and dirt, both from humans and from other creatures. If bacteria and worms did not exist, waste and dirt would pile up because it would not decompose, causing pollution that endangers human life. The deeper one contemplates and observes nature and its events, the deeper one knows the wisdom, use, and purpose of its creation; the more one feels the love and purpose of Allah making humans as khalifah on earth. Only most humans are ungrateful and feel that they are the most powerful and the most capable. In another verse, Allah says:

"Then did you think that We created you uselessly and that to Us you would not be returned?" (al-Mu'minun/23: 115)

And His saying:

"And We did not create the heaven and earth and that between them aimlessly. That is the assumption of those who disbelieve, so woe to those who disbelieve from the Fire." (shad/38: 27)
text.39:
Then Allah affirms that the heavens and the earth and their contents were not created except (as creatures) subject to the true decrees of Allah. Everything is obligated to submit to the applicable and established decrees. If one of God's creatures deviates or does not implement these decrees, then it will feel the consequences of that deviation. Like a banana tree, which is a plant that grows in a place with sufficient water. If it grows in dry land or the desert, it will die. Similarly, with fish; it is ordained to live in water. If it jumps onto land, it will also die. Such is the law of Allah that applies to all of His creatures.

From the above explanation, it can be concluded that the Creator is the One, All-Powerful, and All-Wise Being, therefore all of His creations are obligated to submit and obey His laws, whether consciously or forced. Because all creatures were created based on His *iradah* (will), then based on His *iradah* also will they return to Him later. This occurs because of His majesty and omnipotence.

The diverse and countless creatures of Allah are signs of Allah's power that can be used as material for reflection for those who want to seek the truth. By observing these signs of His power, one can recognize and know how great and how vast is the knowledge of the Creator.

Then Allah regrets the attitude of the polytheists who do not want to understand the signs of Allah's greatness and power that exist in this universe. Their attitude is apparent in their denial of the prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him) and their denial of the Day of Resurrection. This attitude arises because of the arrogance and pride that exists within them, which obscures the clarity of their minds. As a result, they are further away from Allah's mercy and increasingly immersed in the valley of disobedience.
text.40:
In this verse, Allah explains the events that will occur on the Day of Reckoning by affirming that it is the day Allah has designated to deliver judgment to all creatures regarding the reward for their deeds, whether good or bad. On that Day of Decision, the polytheists will be fearful and astonished to see the reality that their assumptions while living in the world were completely devoid of truth. They used to deny the existence of the Day of Reckoning, but in reality, it truly happens.

On that day, all creatures will be driven to the Plain of Gathering (Padang Mahsyar) and assembled to receive a just judgment from Allah. At that time, it will also be proven that the idols they worshipped and sought help from during their lives in the world will not be able to provide them with any benefit or assistance; in fact, those idols will be cast into Hell along with them. The children and families they used to boast about in the world will be of no use and will not be able to help them avoid Allah's punishment.

Allah says:

"Neither your relatives nor your children will ever benefit you on the Day of Resurrection. He will judge between you. And Allah is Seeing of what you do." (al-Mumtahanah/60: 3)

And His saying:

"Indeed, the Day of Decision is a time appointed." (an-Naba'/78: 17)

The only thing that can help and determine a person's fate is their own deeds that they have done during their life in the world. Whoever plants many good deeds will certainly reap abundant rewards from those good deeds. Conversely, whoever follows the desires of their ego will surely receive the torment of hell. Nothing can reduce their torment, even if it is their own child, relatives, or friends. Allah says:

"Then, when the Trumpet is blown, there will be no kinship among them that Day, nor will they ask of one another." (al-Mu'minun/23: 101)

And Allah says:

"And no friend will ask [anything of] a friend, Though they are shown each other..." (al-Ma'arij/70: 10-11)

In this verse, Allah describes the rebuke and mockery uttered by the angels of Zabaniyah to the inhabitants of Hell. The angels said to them, "Taste it, O you who claim to be powerful and noble, taste the recompense for the sins you have committed during your life in the world; as if you were the ones who determined everything, there is no one more powerful than you."

They believed that worldly pleasures were the real pleasures. Therefore, they used their entire lives to obtain those pleasures. They only cared about themselves and did not want to know that their lives actually depended on other people. They even thought that everything they obtained was solely the result of their own hard work, they forgot that it all came from Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Their actions showed that they felt powerful and mighty. But what they experienced on the Day of Recompense was the opposite of what they had previously thought. They felt a painful torment and a very heavy suffering. They felt that they had no value in the presence of the angels who were torturing them. They regretted themselves endlessly.

However, after they were resurrected and driven to the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar) to have their deeds weighed and thrown into the blazing fire, only then did they realize the consequences of their arrogance and stubbornness during their lives in the world. Endless regret arose within them, even though they knew that regret at that time was of no use. Allah says:

"The Day they are forcefully driven into the Fire of Hell, (it will be said), 'This is the Fire which you used to deny.'" (ath-Thur/52: 13-14)

They are under the protection of Allah, and nothing can shake Allah's protection. There are no hurtful words, no attitudes of others that can shake their feelings; everything is pleasant to hear, beautiful to see, soothing to the heart, and calming to the feelings. The place is beautiful, the air is comfortable, and clear springs gush forth water that delights those who live there.

2. In that Paradise, those who believe are given garments made of silk, both fine and soft silk, satisfying the hearts of those who wear them, as well as thick silk of various colors that warms the body.

3. They sit conversing, face to face, in pleasant seating areas. From their faces, only unparalleled happiness and satisfaction with the rewards that Allah has given them radiate.

4. They are bestowed with life companions who accompany them, in the form of spouses or partners who are harmonious and in accordance with their desires. Their spouses have no flaws and have never had their hearts attached to another.

5. They are served with fruits of various kinds and delicious food, inexhaustible and never boring.

Such are the pleasures and happiness that the people of Paradise will obtain later. In reality, this happiness and pleasure cannot be imagined by humans because there is no comparison to it in this life.

In that place, they are safe from all kinds of disturbances, whether in the form of threats to their personal safety or threats to their peace of mind. They are under the protection of Allah, and nothing can shake Allah's protection. There are no hurtful words, no attitudes from others that can shake their feelings, everything is pleasant to hear, beautiful to see, soothing to the heart and calming to the feelings, the place is beautiful, the air is comfortable, the clear springs gush forth water that delights those who live in it.

2. In that Paradise, the believers are given garments made of silk, both fine and soft silk, satisfying the hearts of those who wear them, as well as thick silk of various colors that warms the body.

3. They sit and converse, facing each other in pleasant seating places. From their faces, only unparalleled happiness and satisfaction with the rewards that Allah has given them radiate.

4. They are granted life partners to accompany them, in the form of spouses or partners who are harmonious and in accordance with their desires. Their partners have no flaws and have never had their hearts attached to anyone else.

5. They are served fruits of various kinds and delicious food, which never runs out and is never boring.

Such are the pleasures and happiness that the people of Paradise will obtain later. In reality, this happiness and pleasure cannot be imagined by humans because there is no comparison to it in this life.

text.56:
In this verse, Allah explains another pleasure that He will bestow in Paradise, which is that they will not experience death as they did in the world. They will live eternally in Paradise. This means that the inhabitants of Paradise will remain in a state of physical and spiritual well-being, and they will have ascended to a level that Allah has not granted to other creatures, except for angels, which is eternal life full of happiness.

In a hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (saw) narrated by Muslim, the condition of the inhabitants of Paradise is described as follows:

"Narrated by Abu Hurairah and Abu Sa'id that the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, a caller will call out, "Indeed, you will always be healthy, therefore you will never suffer from illness forever; indeed, you will remain alive and will not die forever, and indeed, you will remain young and will never experience old age forever, and indeed, you will feel pleasure and will not suffer forever." (Riwayat Muslim)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that the inhabitants of Paradise are protected from the torment of Hell. Being protected from torment is one of the most precious blessings, because when someone escapes from a danger or sees others suffering while they themselves are free from danger and suffering, they will feel a blessing and feel that they have never committed a crime so that they do not experience suffering.
text.57: All the blessings received by the inhabitants of Paradise are Allah's bounty, given as a sign that He is pleased with the deeds they performed during their lives in the world, and as proof that they followed the guidance of the revelation that Allah conveyed to His Messenger, obedient to the commands they had to carry out and abstaining from all the prohibitions they had to stop. They receive this as a result of the efforts they have made and a reward for their faith. The result they obtain is unparalleled when compared to the results anyone has ever achieved during their life in the world, enjoying the fruits of their own labor, which is a unique pleasure in itself.
text.58:
Allah explains the guidance and warnings that have been conveyed to the polytheists of Mecca by His Messenger, Muhammad (peace be upon him), in the form of His revelation, which was revealed in a language they already understood, namely their own language, Arabic. This was intended so that the polytheists of Mecca could easily take guidance and lessons from the fundamental principles of Islam, parables, and stories of past nations that are found in the Qur'an, the revelation that has been revealed. By reading the Qur'an, they would contemplate the verses that command people to pay attention to the signs of Allah's power and greatness that are found in the creation of the heavens and the earth and what is between them, as well as the proofs of the existence of the Day of Resurrection.

With that guidance and warning, it was hoped that they would repent, return to the right path, be willing to acknowledge and seek the true truth by abandoning the customs of their ancestors that had clearly gone astray. However, due to the hardness of their hearts because of their arrogance and pride, the guidance and truth presented to them by the Qur'an could not be accepted, so they remained in darkness and error.
text.59:
That is why Allah allows the polytheists of Mecca to stray in their polytheism, letting them await Allah's decree at the appointed time. They will surely witness for themselves who is right in the end: those who always associate partners with God and commit sins, or those who believe and follow the teachings of revelation conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad.

If they were willing to acknowledge the truth of the Qur'an, they would certainly be convinced that victory would be achieved by those who follow the religion of monotheism, striving and working to seek Allah's pleasure. Allah says:

"Indeed, We will support Our messengers and those who believe during the life of this world and on the Day when the witnesses will stand - The Day their excuse will not benefit the wrongdoers, and they will have the curse, and they will have the worst home." (Gafir/40: 51-52)

While awaiting Allah's decree, there were differences in attitude and belief between the followers of the Messenger and the polytheists of Mecca. The followers of the Messenger awaited Allah's promise of victory with patience and reliance (tawakal). They were certain that Allah would fulfill His promise, namely to grant victory to Islam and the Muslims in this world and bestow eternal blessings and happiness in the Hereafter. Therefore, they were never daunted or afraid; death and life were the same to them because everything they possessed, soul and body, wealth and life, they had surrendered to Allah. Conversely, the polytheists waited with feelings of anxiety and fear. They were very worried about being destroyed by the Muslims. Every time they saw the progress, advancement, and victory of the Muslims over them, their anxiety increased. They were very afraid of the Muslims' revenge on them. Therefore, they tried their best and poured out everything they had to overcome the progress and victory of the Muslims.

This is evident in their efforts, as they had striven in the Battle of the Trench (Ahzab), the Treaty of Hudaybiyah, and so on. Actually, in their hearts, they imagined the real truth, but because of arrogance and pride, they still distanced themselves from the truth of the Qur'an.
